author: Saleen Martin
title: 'May this keep you safe from harm': WWII era Bible returned to New York veteran's family
text: Lost Bible returned to slain USAAF airman from World War II [Saleen Martin](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/7245115001/saleen-martin/) During World War II, a woman bought three brothers Bibles to protect their hearts and guide them as they set out for battle. The Bible had a metal cover on the front with the inscription ‚ÄúMay this keep you safe from harm." Two of the brothers made it home, while the other, Lt. Edsel J. McKnight of the United States Army Air Forces, was shot down off the coast of France. His Bible was mailed to the family but was lost sometime after. This month, his family finally got it back. Ava Coogan's family is from Albany, New York and they found the Bible in late December while going through their late matriarch‚Äôs belongings. On Jan. 11, Coogan met Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law and returned the Bible to her, allowing her to put it back in its rightful place, next to the ones his brothers brought back home from war. ‚ÄòI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages‚Äô Coogan‚Äôs uncle and mother found the Bible in a stack of books. Their mother, Rosanne Vartanian, died nearly 20 years ago but was a collector and loved garage sales. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just so random that my grandmother had the urge to pick that up,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúShe bought random things. There was no rhyme or reason to it. It was with a stack of other books.‚Äù Coogan decided to research the Bible and found out soldiers often took them to war. Some can be found in museums. ‚ÄúThe whole premise of it was that the metal cover on the front is like a hard shield,‚Äù Coogan told USA TODAY. ‚ÄúThey would put it in their coat pockets ‚Ä¶ like the front breast pocket ‚Ä¶ that cover would protect their heart from bullets.‚Äù Lt. McKnight‚Äôs name was also written in the Bible, said Coogan, who was drawn to the Bible for some reason. She couldn‚Äôt put it down, she recalled. ‚ÄúI kept playing with it and flipping through the pages,‚Äù she said. She noticed that the Bible‚Äôs front cover had a slice in it, almost like something was underneath it. She examined it more closely and found a piece of paper folded up inside. She asked her uncle for help, who carefully used a butter knife to get the slip of paper out. Once they retrieved the piece of paper from under the Bible‚Äôs cover, they saw that it was a plea for the Bible‚Äôs safe return to an address not too far away. Although there was no area code, there was a phone number listed, so the family added their own area code and called. ‚ÄúI was just hoping for the best,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúWe found out that number worked.‚Äù Lieutenant was shot down off the coast of France When Coogan called the number written in the note, she spoke to a woman named Fay, Lt. McKnight‚Äôs sister-in-law. They organized a meetup on Jan. 11 to return the Bible to the family, who is from Porter Corners, part of Saratoga County in eastern New York. Lt. McKnight served in the U.S. Air Force‚Äôs 365th Fighter Group and 388th Fighter Squadron. He was flying in a Thunderbolt fighter aircraft in 1944 when he was shot down off the coast of France, [online records](https://rafbeaulieu.co.uk/honouring-the-airmen-of-raf-beaulieu/) show. Fay told Coogan and her family that Lt. McKnight has two brothers. All three of the brothers served in WWII. Fay‚Äôs husband, Ray, said his Bible saved his life. ‚ÄúHe got shot during the war and it hit where the Bible was, covering his heart, and the bullet went into his arm instead,‚Äù Coogan said. Once Lt. McKnight was killed, his belongings were shipped back home to the family. His sister-in-law had all three Bibles on a bookshelf on display. One day, the family was preparing to go to church. Her nephew borrowed the Bible, but knew it was so precious, the family decided to write a note with contact information in case it were ever lost. ‚ÄúHe didn't lose it,‚Äù Coogan said. ‚ÄúHe brought it back after church and I guess what happened is after someone passed in their family, they had an estate sale ‚Ä¶ and it just accidentally went out with a stack of books.‚Äù It ended up in Coogan‚Äôs grandmother‚Äôs hands, she said. Returning the Bible to the McKnight family was quite the enlightening experience, Coogan said. ‚ÄúThat was really cool because that's when we kind of got to hear their story,‚Äù she said.

author: Simonnfugs Ampedpages Com
title: 7 Ways Mobile App Expert Can Optimize App Performance
text:
Introduction to Mobile App Expert Performance
Welcome to the world of mobile app expertise, where performance is key! In today's fast-paced digital landscape, users expect nothing less than seamless and lightning-fast experiences from their favorite apps. Whether it's a gaming app, social media platform, or productivity tool, optimizing app performance has become an essential aspect of success for any mobile application.
But why is optimizing app performance so important? Well, think about it - would you continue using an app that takes ages to load or crashes frequently? Probably not! Users are increasingly impatient and have high expectations when it comes to the performance of the apps they use on a daily basis. That's where mobile app experts come in ‚Äì these skilled professionals possess the know-how to fine-tune and optimize applications for optimal speed and functionality.
In this blog post, we'll delve into the various factors that can impact your mobile app's performance and discuss seven tried-and-tested ways in which a mobile app expert can help you optimize its overall efficiency. So grab your smartphones and get ready to discover how you can enhance your app's performance like never before!
Importance of Optimizing App Performance
In today's highly competitive mobile app expert market, optimizing app performance is crucial for success. With millions of apps available for download, users have high expectations when it comes to the performance of their chosen apps.
A slow or glitchy app can lead to frustration and ultimately result in users abandoning mobile app expert altogether.
Optimizing app performance not only enhances user experience but also contributes to increased user retention and engagement. When an app runs smoothly without any hiccups, users are more likely to keep using it and even recommend it to others. This word-of-mouth marketing can greatly benefit your app's visibility and downloads.
There are several factors that affect app performance, such as network connectivity, device compatibility, and coding efficiency. By understanding these factors and addressing them effectively, mobile app experts can optimize the overall performance of their apps.
One important aspect of optimizing app performance is minimizing load times. Users expect fast-loading screens and responsive interactions when using an app. By reducing unnecessary data loads or implementing caching mechanisms, developers can significantly improve loading speed.
Another factor that plays a significant role in optimizing performance is memory management. Apps that consume excessive memory tend to slow down devices and drain battery life quickly. Mobile app expert should focus on efficient memory allocation techniques to ensure optimal resource utilization.
Furthermore, ensuring smooth navigation within the app is crucial for a seamless user experience. Mobile app expert must pay attention to how users navigate through different screens or sections within the application by implementing intuitive design elements like clear navigation menus or gesture-based controls.
Regular testing throughout the development process helps identify any potential bottlenecks or issues that might impact overall performance negatively after launch. Conducting thorough testing on different devices with varying configurations will allow developers to address any compatibility issues early on.
Additionally, monitoring real-time analytics data provides valuable insights into how users interact with an application under various conditions (e.g., peak usage times). This information enables mobile app expert to identify areas where optimization is required continually.
Understanding the Different Factors Affecting App Performance
When it comes to mobile app performance, there are several factors that can have a significant impact. One of the key factors is the overall design and architecture of the app. The way an app is built can determine how efficiently it functions and how quickly it responds to user actions.
Another important factor is the size of the app. Apps that are too large can take up valuable storage space on a user's device, which can slow down overall performance. It's crucial for developers to optimize their apps by reducing file sizes and removing unnecessary features or resources.
Network connectivity also plays a vital role in app performance. Slow or unstable internet connections can result in sluggish loading times and poor user experience. Developers should ensure that their apps are designed to handle different network conditions gracefully, such as implementing caching mechanisms or using compression techniques to minimize data usage.
The device itself is another element that affects app performance. Older devices with limited processing power may struggle to run resource-intensive apps smoothly, leading to lagging and crashes. Developers should consider optimizing their apps for different device specifications and testing them on various devices before release.
App updates also play a crucial role in maintaining optimal performance. Regularly updating an app not only adds new features but also fixes bugs and improves overall stability. Keeping up with OS updates is equally essential since new versions often come with performance enhancements or bug fixes.
Efficient memory management is critical for ensuring smooth app operation. Poor memory management practices can lead to excessive memory consumption, resulting in slower response times or even crashes. By implementing effective memory management techniques like garbage collection or object pooling, developers can significantly enhance their app's performance.
Understanding the different factors affecting mobile app performance is vital for delivering a high-quality user experience. By taking into account aspects such as design architecture, file size optimization, network connectivity considerations, device compatibility testing, regular updates, and efficient memory management,
mobile app experts can optimize their apps to perform at their best.
7 Ways to Optimize Mobile App Performance:
1. Efficient Code: A mobile app expert knows that writing efficient code is crucial for optimizing app performance. By minimizing unnecessary code and using best practices, the app can run smoothly and respond quickly to user interactions.
2. Image Optimization: Images are an integral part of many apps, but they can also slow down performance if not optimized correctly. Mobile app experts understand the importance of compressing images without sacrificing quality, reducing file sizes and improving load times.
3. Caching: Caching allows the app to store frequently accessed data locally on the device, reducing the need for constant network requests. An experienced app expert will implement caching techniques strategically to enhance overall performance.
4.
hire a good Mobile App Expert Battery Optimization: App performance is closely tied to battery consumption. By optimizing power usage through techniques such as background process management, push notifications optimization, and efficient use of sensors, a mobile app expert ensures that users can enjoy uninterrupted usage without draining their batteries too quickly.
5. Network Efficiency: Slow network connections can hinder app performance significantly. Experts optimize network requests by minimizing unnecessary data transfers and implementing strategies like lazy loading or prefetching content to reduce latency and provide a seamless user experience.
6. User Interface (UI) Design Considerations: A well-designed UI not only enhances user experience but also impacts overall performance. Mobile app experts focus on creating intuitive interfaces with minimal animations and transitions that don't strain system resources or cause delays in response time.
7. Regular Testing & Monitoring: Optimizing an app's performance is an ongoing process that requires continuous testing and monitoring by a knowledgeable professional who understands how different factors affect its speed and responsiveness.
By employing these seven strategies, a mobile app expert maximizes an application's potential while providing users with a fast, reliable experience.
Conclusion: The Ongoing Process of App Optimization
Optimizing the performance of a mobile app expert is not a one-time task, but rather an ongoing process.
As technology evolves and user expectations continue to rise, it becomes crucial for mobile app expert to continuously monitor and improve the performance of their apps.
By implementing the seven strategies discussed in this article - optimizing code, reducing network requests, managing memory efficiently, prioritizing user experience, testing across devices and networks, monitoring app performance in real-time, and using analytics data for optimization - mobile app expert can significantly enhance the overall performance of their apps.
Remember that every small improvement counts when it comes to enhancing mobile app expert It's essential to stay up-to-date with emerging trends in mobile technology and regularly evaluate your app's performance against industry benchmarks. By doing so, you can ensure that your app remains competitive in today's fast-paced digital landscape.
So don't settle for mediocre performance! Embrace these optimization techniques as part of your development process and watch as your app delivers exceptional user experiences while standing out from the crowd.
Becoming a successful mobile app expert requires not only technical expertise but also a commitment to continually optimize the performance of your apps. Stay proactive and dedicated to providing users with flawless experiences on their smartphones or tablets. By doing so, you will maximize user satisfaction while achieving long-term success in the highly competitive world of mobile applications.
7 Ways Mobile App Expert Can Optimize App Performance
Introduction to Mobile App Expert Performance

author: ArcaMax Publishing, Inc.
title: Wolf connected to livestock killings could be breeding, wildlife officials say | News & Features | ArcaMax Publishing
text: Wolf connected to livestock killings could be breeding, wildlife officials say Published in [News & Features](/currentnews/newsheadlines/) Wildlife officials said they will not remove a gray wolf potentially connected to recent livestock killings, despite requests from stockgrowers. Two of the gray wolves reintroduced to Colorado‚Äôs Grand County in December ‚Äî including one suspected in recent depredations ‚Äî are likely ‚Äúdenning‚Äù and in the breeding process, Colorado Parks and Wildlife officials said in a letter to the Middle Park Stockgrowers Board Tuesday. The letter came in response to a request from the board to lethally remove two wolves suspected in the livestock attacks. Removing the male wolf ‚Äúwould be irresponsible management and potentially cause the den to fail, possibly resulting in the death of the presumed pups,‚Äù CPW Director Jeff Davis wrote in Tuesday‚Äôs letter. In early April, the female wolf‚Äôs GPS stopped uploading location points to the server and only started uploading again recently, according to Davis. Officials believe she was in the den, which interrupted the tracking collar‚Äôs signal and aligns with the expected timing of wolf reproduction. CPW officers are working to confirm the den‚Äôs location. Colorado‚Äôs first confirmed wolf depredation incident happened on April 2 in Grand County. The second attack came just five days later, 60 miles north in Jackson County. On April 18, the total number of livestock killed by wolves reached six as wildlife officials confirmed two more calf attacks. Amid reports of livestock attacks and depredations, one of the 10 gray wolves reintroduced to Colorado was found dead in Larimer County, federal officials confirmed Tuesday. Initial evidence shows the wolf likely died of natural causes, but an official autopsy has not yet been completed. ‚ÄúThe wolf population in Colorado is far below any restoration goal,‚Äù Davis wrote in Tuesday‚Äôs letter. ‚ÄúWe have the legal duty to establish a self-sustaining population of wolves while minimizing conflict risk.‚Äù As the wolf population in Colorado grows, the approach to lethal removals will likely become more liberal, Davis wrote.

author: Editorial Team
title: One-quarter of employers planning pay rises of at least 5% in 2024 - HR News
text: Nearly a quarter (24%) of employers predict that the main pay rise for staff in 2024 is likely to be at least 5%, according to an IDR poll of 158 mostly large private sector organisations. The research also revealed that nearly half of employers ‚Äì some 46% ‚Äì said they intend to award increases of between 4% and 4.99%. While increases worth at least 4% are set to continue, the poll also found that two-thirds of employers anticipate that their 2024 pay award will be a lower increase when compared to this year. A further 27% said that the level of pay rise in 2024 is likely to be the same as the level of increase awarded in 2023 and just 7% of employers in the sample expect that pay awards in 2024 will be higher when compared to this year‚Äôs outcomes. These findings hint at an easing of pay pressures and that pay awards will most likely trend downwards from the median pay award of 5.6% that we have observed in 2023. ‚ÄúAlthough the coming trend in pay awards is likely to be down on the past year, on the whole they are likely to remain higher than they were prior to 2023‚Äù, commented Zoe Woolacott from IDR. Median for January at 4.4% IDR‚Äôs regular monitoring of pay outcomes bears out the findings from the poll. Our monitoring of pay awards shows that the median pay increase across the economy in 2023 was 5.6% but an early look at outcomes already decided for 2024 shows that the median pay award across the economy has fallen and currently stands at 4.4%. These latest figures are based on a sample of 42 awards effective between 1 January and 31 October 2024, mostly at large organisations and together covering over 140,000 employees. The results predominantly reflect the picture in the private sector. Higher-end awards worth 4% or more represent over three-fifths (62%) of deals effective in 2024 so far ‚Äì down from 86% of awards in 2023. Affordability and competitiveness are key influences on pay Survey participants were asked to indicate the main influences on their organisations‚Äô pay decisions for 2024. Affordability and pressure to remain competitive proved to be the top two factors with around four-fifths of respondents citing these as one of the main influences ‚Äì 85% and 80% respectively. The third most influential factor in pay decisions this year is inflation, as indicated by 69% of participants. This proportion, while it has fallen from 85% in a similar poll we conducted regarding pay intentions for 2023, shows that inflation and the cost of living continues to figure highly in employers‚Äô concerns regarding pay. The next most influential factor was employee morale and motivation. This was followed by the National Living Wage (cited by 34% of employers in the sample), while a smaller proportion (29%) indicated that the ‚Äòreal living wage‚Äô (a voluntary rate based on estimations of the wage needed to provide a socially acceptable standard of living and which takes the cost of living into greater account that the statutory floor) will be an influence on their pay decisions for 2024.

author: Joe Dejka Omaha World-Herald
title: Some Nebraskans will be toasting a pay hike on Jan. 1
text:
The Economic Policy Institute estimates that 91,000 Nebraska workers ‚Äî 9.5% of Nebraska‚Äôs workforce ‚Äî saw a wage increase when the state‚Äôs minimum wage went up on Jan. 1, 2024.‚Äã
The bump is the second in a series of annual increases voters approved in 2022.
Ballot Initiative 433 was an effort of Raise the Wage Nebraska, largely supported financially by labor unions and various progressive organizations.
On Jan. 1, 2023, the minimum wage went from $9 an hour to $10.50 an hour. It will increase to $13.50 on Jan. 1, 2025, and to $15 on Jan. 1, 2026.
People are also reading‚Ä¶ Man found dead in NW Lincoln lake after report of submerged car Fourth generation set to lead Lincoln's largest bank Lincoln man lied on food stamp application, defrauded government of more than $25K, officials say Grain elevator in the heart of Lincoln up for sale Minnesota All-American outside hitter Taylor Landfair transfers to Nebraska Lancaster County Sheriff to put six automatic license plate readers along I-80 Amie Just: Predicting 2024 for Nebraska Athletics ‚Äî and beyond Driver violated red light in 70th Street and Nebraska Parkway crash, LPD says Ruling allows Nebraska employees to continue working remotely ‚Äî for now These 4 moms, home in Waterloo for the holidays, always can ask a sister for baby advice Shooting suspect arrested in I-80 traffic stop, Nebraska State Patrol says LFR responds to fire at Lazlo's in south Lincoln Nebraska football reserve linebacker enters transfer portal Double blessings: Twin brothers welcome babies on same day in Lincoln Alvo couple welcomes first baby of 2024 in Lincoln Rebecca Firestone, executive director of Nebraska's Open Sky Policy Institute, said the gradual increases will help Nebraskans.
"Hardworking Nebraskans deserve an economy that respects their work and enables them to support their families and contribute to their communities," Firestone said.
The increase will help to reduce racial income disparity and provide low- and middle-income Nebraskans with much needed protection against inflation, she said.
Mark Whitehead, chair of the Lincoln Independent Business Association, said the change in the minimum wage is less important than market forces. A strong economy, he said, means a lower unemployment rate and produces higher pay.
"The Lincoln labor market has been well below effectively zero unemployment, as defined as 4% by most economists, for a significant number of years," he said. "As such, for almost all service-level businesses, the minimum wage is irrelevant. The market dictates a much higher rate."
Listen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | Omny Studio
Most businesses in the service sector are paying far more than $12 an hour, he said.
There may be some association members that are currently at $10.50 per hour, but he said they have developed strategies that drive value to their associates beyond the pay offered.
"Moving that rate to $12 per hour would have to get them to rethink their strategies on how they will continue to survive and hopefully thrive in this new environment," he said. ‚Äã
‚ÄãNebraska is among 22 states that raised the minimum wage Jan. 1, according to Forbes Advisor.
For workers who are mainly compensated by tips, such as waitresses, waiters and bus persons, the Nebraska minimum hourly pay rate is $2.13 per hour. The sum of the $2.13 per hour plus all tips given to the individual must equal or exceed the required minimum wage for all hours worked.‚Äã‚Äã
Neighboring states also set new minimums: Colorado, $14.42; Missouri, $12.30; South Dakota, $11.20.
The minimum wage in Iowa and Kansas is $7.25 an hour, same as the federal minimum, according to the U.S. Department of Labor. The federal minimum wage has not increased since July 2009.
Across the country, an estimated 9.9 million workers will receive an increase, the Economic Policy Institute reported.
In total, workers will receive $6.95 billion in additional wages from state minimum wage increases, it said. In addition, 38 cities and counties will increase their minimum wages on Jan. 1 above their state‚Äôs wage floors, adding to the number of workers likely to see increased earnings, it said.
At the start of the new year, 22 states and 43 cities and counties are increasing the hourly minimum wage, benefiting nearly 10 million people. And that doesn't only affect workers at major fast food chains or retail outlets; it also includes people who work at small, locally-owned businesses.

author: @KFYRTV
title: 4-year-old and infant in Colorado found safe after endangered missing alert
text: 4-year-old and infant in Colorado found safe after endangered missing alert STERLING, Colo. ( [KKTV](https://www.kktv.com/2023/12/28/statewide-alert-issued-colorado-missing-4-year-old-infant/)/Gray News) - A statewide alert issued in Colorado on Thursday for two young children has been canceled, [KKTV reports.](https://www.kktv.com/2023/12/28/statewide-alert-issued-colorado-missing-4-year-old-infant/) The Colorado Bureau of Investigation issued an alert for 4-year-old Zuryah Thalacker and 23-month-old Ansom Thalacker. Officials say the two children were located and were safe as of 3 p.m. on Thursday. Officials say the children have been missing since Wednesday at 1:30 p.m. when they were last seen in the Sterling area. The alert stated that the children may have been with 28-year-old Justina Lambert. The CBI did not disclose the relationship between the three in the alert. The alert said the children were believed to be traveling in a 2007 White Nissan Murano with CA license plate 9ERA912, with the rear bumper missing. Copyright 2023 KKTV via Gray Media Group, Inc. All rights reserved.
